facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 134 of 1962 filed by special leave from Andhra Pradesh High Court judgment dated July 17, 1962 in Criminal Revision Case No. 298 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 134 of 1962. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 17, 1962 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Criminal Revision Case No. 298 of 1961.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 23, 1964 by RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.

anchor.surface_text: March 23, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.-The facts leading to this appeal, by special leave, are these The Madras Public Service Commission,

facts.text: Madras Public Service Commission published notification in Fort St. George Gazette dated August 3, 1948 inviting applications for Assistant Surgeons in Madras Medical Service Mens Section from temporary service holders between September 3, 1939 and December 31, 1947 or War Service with qualifications.

anchor.surface_text: The Madras Public Service Commission, hereinafter referred to as the Service Commission, by its numberification published in the Fort St. George Gazette dated August 3, 1948, invited applications for appointment of Assistant Surgeons in the Madras Medical Service  Mens Section , from persons who had rendered temporary service as Assistant Surgeons in that Service at any time between September 3, 1939 and December 31, 1947 and from persons who had rendered War Service and possessed the qualifications mentioned in paragraph 3 of the numberification.

facts.text: Paragraph 3 of notification requires applicants to be registered practitioners under Madras Medical Registration Act, 1914 and possess L.M.S. degree or M.B., B.S. degree or equivalent.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 3 of the numberification, inter alia, reads Applicants must satisfy the Commission--  a  that they are registered practitioners within the meaning of the Madras Medical Registration Act, 1914  b  that they possess the L.M.S. degree or the M.B., B.S., degree of a University in the Province or an equivalent qualification.

facts.text: Appellant was serving as Civil Assistant Surgeon in Madras Medical Service on temporary basis at the time of application.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, who was at the time serving as a Civil Assistant Surgeon in the Madras Medical Service on a tempo- rary basis, applied for the permanent appointment to the posts -notified by the Public Service Commission.

facts.text: Appellant made false representations in application: name Kaza Krishnamurthy, place of birth Bezwada Krishna district, father K. R. Rao of Bezwada, held M.B.B.S. II Class from Andhra Medical College Vizagapatam Andhra University.

anchor.surface_text: In this application he made the following representations, which have been found to be false, by the Courts below that his name was Kaza Krishnamurthy that his place of birth was Bezwada, Krishna district that his father was K. R. Rao of Bezwada and that he held the degree of M.B.B.S., II Class, from the Andhra Medical College, Vizagapatam, Andhra University.

facts.text: Appellant convicted of offence under s. 419 I.P.C. for cheating Madras Public Service Commission by personating and misrepresenting qualifications.

anchor.surface_text: On these facts, the appellant was companyvicted of the offence under s. 419 I.P.C. for having cheated the Madras Public Service Commission by personating as Kaza Krishnamurthy and misrepresenting that he had the necessary qualifications for the post advertised inasmuch as he held the degree of B.B.S., and that this deception of the Service Commission was likely to have caused damage to its reputation.

facts.text: Appellant also tried for offences under s. 420 and s. 465 I.P.C. in connection with acts in June and October 1944.

anchor.surface_text: It may number be mentioned that the appellant was also tried for offences under s. 420 and s. 465 I.P.C. in companynection with certain acts companymitted by him in June and October, 1944.

facts.text: Trial court acquitted appellant of s. 465 but convicted under s. 420; Sessions Judge acquitted of s. 420 but confirmed s. 419 conviction; High Court dismissed revision against s. 419.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court acquitted him of the offence under s. 465, but companyvicted him of the other offence. He was, however, acquitted on appeal, by the Sessions Judge, of the offence under s. 420 I.P.C. The appellants companyviction under s. 419 I.P.C. was companyfirmed by the Sessions Judge and the revision against that order was dismissed by the High Court.

facts.text: Appellant secured good reports from superiors during service period; efficiency not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: It has been companytended for the appellant that on the facts, established in the case, numberoffence under s. 419 I.P.C. is made out against him, as the appellants efficiency as a surgeon is number in dispute, he having secured good reports from his superiors during the period of his service

facts.text: Appellant served efficiently for about 10 years between appointment and institution of case, obtained good reports from departmental superiors.

anchor.surface_text: On the companytrary, the evidence on the record shows that for about 10 years between his appointment and the institution of this case, he served efficiently and obtained good reports from the Departmental Superiors.

facts.text: No competitive written examination took place; candidates interviewed by Service Commission.

anchor.surface_text: In fact, numberexamination as such took place, and the companytention for the respondent appears to have been made under a misapprehension arising out of the letter of the Secretary of the Service Commission to the Surgeon- General with the Government of Madras stating that he was enclosing the list companytaining the names and other particulars of 45 candidates who were successful at the companypetitive examination held by the Commission for the direct recruitment of Civil Assistant Surgeons, Class II  Men  in the Madras Medical Service.

facts.text: Appellant interviewed by Service Commission and selected as Civil Assistant Surgeon Class II.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the Magistrate states The accused was interviewed by the Service Commission as seen from Exhibit P-70, extract of Service Commission particulars.

facts.text: Service Commission selected appellant following interview and recommended to Government.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court states the same in its judgment. It said In 1948 he sent an application to the Madras public Service Commission for selection as class 11 Civil Assistant Surgeon and was selected as such following an interview by the said body.

facts.text: Appointments to Medical Services made by Government on recommendation of Service Commission.

anchor.surface_text: The ap- pointments to the Medical Services are made by Government. The Service Commission simply selected the candidates and recommends their names to Government for appointment.

facts.text: Service Commission sent list of selected candidates including qualifications to Surgeon-General with Government of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: This is clear from letter Exhibit P. 47 from the Secretary to the Service Commission to the Surgeon-General with the Government of Madras. The letter refers to the enclosing of a list companytaining the names and other particulars of the candidates who were successful at the examination,

facts.text: Government believed appellant possessed MBBS degree based on Service Commission recommendation and scrutiny.

anchor.surface_text: The Government therefore believed that the appellant possessed the degree of M.B.,B.S., that as the Service Commission had scrutinized the application in that regard and had satisfied itself that the appellant possessed that degree.

facts.text: Appellant's incompetency due to not obtaining minimum academic qualifications.

anchor.surface_text: His incompetency for the post was due to his having number obtained the minimum academic qualifications prescribed for the candidates for these posts.

facts.text: Public Service Commission is statutory body independent of Government constituted under Government of India Act, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: This is also clear from the provisions of the Government of India Act, 1935. Section 241 provided that appointments in companynection with the affairs of a Province will be made by the Governor of the Province.

facts.text: Appellant deceived Government by misrepresentation persisting till appointment order.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the appellants misre- presentation to the Service Commission companytinued and persisted till the final stage of the Government passing an order of appointment and that therefore the Government itself was deceived by the misrepresentation he had made in his application presented to the Service Commission.

The appellants companyviction under s. 419 I.P.C. was companyfirmed by the Sessions Judge and the revision against that order was dismissed by the High Court.

Section 415 I.P.C., defines cheating and reads Whoever, by deceiving any person, fraudulently ordishonestly induces the person so deceived to deliver any property to any person, or to companysent that any person shall retain any property, or intentionally induces the person so deceived to do or omit to do anything which he would number do or omit if he were number so deceived, and which act or omission causes or is likely to cause damage or harm to that person in body, mind, reputation or property, is said to cheat.

concepts.interpretation: Deception must induce delivery of property or act/omission causing or likely to cause damage/harm; analyzed for both PSC and Government.

We are therefore of opinion that the appellants misre- presentation to the Service Commission companytinued and persisted till the final stage of the Government passing an order of appointment and that therefore the Government itself was deceived by the misrepresentation he had made in his application presented to the Service Commission.

issues.text: whether on the facts established in the case, no offence under s. 419 I.P.C. is made out against him, as the appellant's efficiency as a surgeon is not in dispute... and as therefore there could be no question of the Service Commission suffering damage in its reputation

anchor.surface_text: It has been contended for the appellant that on the facts, established in the case, no offence under s. 419 I.P.C. is made out against him, as the appellants efficiency as a surgeon is not in dispute, he having secured good reports from his superiors during the period of his service and as therefore there could be no question of the Service Commission suffering damage in its reputation.

issues.text: whether the appellant cheated the Service Commission by deceiving that he held the degree of M.B.B.S. and by intentionally inducing the Commission to recommend his appointment... and that this act... was likely to damage its reputation

anchor.surface_text: The Courts below, as already stated, found that the appellant cheated the Service Commission by deceiving that he held the degree of M.B.B.S. and by intentionally inducing the Commission to recommend his appointment to the post of Civil Assistant Surgeon, II Class, and that this act of the Service Commission was likely to damage its reputation as the appellant did not really possess the degree of M.B.,B.S.

issues.text: whether the appellant... induced by deception the Service Commission to deliver to him the admission card which is property, committing the offence of cheating as defined in the first part of s. 415 I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued for the State that the Public Service Commission held a competitive examination and must have therefore issued an admission card to the appellant entitling him to sit at that competitive examination and that therefore the appellant having induced by deception the Service Commission to deliver to him the admission card which is property, committed the offence of cheating as defined in the first part of s. 415 I.P.C.

issues.text: whether the appellant deceived the Government of Madras and dishonestly induced it to deliver something in the form of salary to the appellant

anchor.surface_text: The only other question to determine now is whether the appellant deceived the Government of Madras and dishonestly induced it to deliver something in the form of salary to the appellant.

issues.text: whether the person deceived was the Service Commission and not the Government, given that the application containing the misrepresentation was made to the Service Commission

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, it is contended for the appellant that the delivery of property is to be by the person deceived, in view of the language of s. 415 I.P.C., and that the person deceived, if any, was the Service Commission and not the Government, the application containing the misrepresentation having been made to the Service Commission and not to the Government.

issues.text: whether a false representation in an application to the Service Commission continues till considered by the Government, the final appointing authority, such that the Government is deceived

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the appellants misrepresentation to the Service Commission continued and persisted till the final stage of the Government passing an order of appointment and that therefore the Government itself was deceived by the misrepresentation he had made in his application presented to the Service Commission.

arguments.claim: No offence under s. 419 I.P.C. is made out as appellant's efficiency as a surgeon is not in dispute, having secured good reports, so no damage to Service Commission's reputation

anchor.surface_text: It has been contended for the appellant that on the facts, established in the case, no offence under s. 419 I.P.C. is made out against him, as the appellants efficiency as a surgeon is not in dispute, he having secured good reports from his superiors during the period of his service and as therefore there could be no question of the Service Commission suffering damage in its reputation.

arguments.court_reasoning: No likelihood of damage to reputation as appellant served efficiently for 10 years with good reports

arguments.claim: Person deceived was Service Commission not Government, as application made to Commission and delivery must be by person deceived per s. 415 I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, it is contended for the appellant that the delivery of property is to be by the person deceived, in view of the language of s. 415 I.P.C., and that the person deceived, if any, was the Service Commission and not the Government, the application containing the misrepresentation having been made to the Service Commission and not to the Government.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: mpanycerned. In such cases, the person deceiving the servants or agents has been held to have deceived the authority companycerned, though numberdirec

arguments.court_reasoning: Misrepresentation to Service Commission continued and persisted till Government appointment order

arguments.claim: Offence of cheating made out as deceived Service Commission likely to damage its reputation, obtained admission card as property, and deceived Government to appoint and pay salary

anchor.surface_text: On the contrary, it is urged for the State that the offence of cheating is made out against the appellant as he deceived the Service Commission and that such deception was likely to damage its reputation as he deceived the Service Commission and obtained from it property viz., the admission card entitling him to sit at the Competitive Examination for the appointment of candidates for these posts, and as the appellant also deceived the Government of the State by his false representations, and dishonestly induced it to appoint him in service and pay him salary during the period of his service.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: We accept the companytention for the respondent. The ap- pointments to the Medical Services are made by Government. The Service Commission simply sele

arguments.court_reasoning: Rejected damage to PSC and admission card parts, accepted deception of Government

arguments.claim: Public Service Commission held competitive examination, issued admission card as property, so cheating by inducing delivery under first part of s. 415 I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued for the State that the Public Service Commission held a competitive examination and must have therefore issued an admission card to the appellant entitling him to sit at that competitive examination and that therefore the appellant having induced by deception the Service Commission to deliver to him the admission card which is property, committed the offence of cheating as defined in the first part of s. 415 I.P.C.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the examination, their names being arranged in order of merit. It refers to the relaxing of a certain rule in view of the paucity of candidates and st

arguments.court_reasoning: No evidence of competitive written examination or admission card; only interview took place

arguments.claim: Appellant cheated Service Commission by deceiving re MBBS degree, inducing recommendation for appointment, likely to damage reputation as no degree

anchor.surface_text: The Courts below, as already stated, found that the appellant cheated the Service Commission by deceiving that he held the degree of M.B.B.S. and by intentionally inducing the Commission to recommend his appointment to the post of Civil Assistant Surgeon, II Class, and that this act of the Service Commission was likely to damage its reputation as the appellant did not really possess the degree of M.B.,B.S.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: t is however clear from the record that the candidates were simply interviewed by the Commission. There is numberhing on the record to show that any w

arguments.court_reasoning: No likelihood of damage as appellant served efficiently 10 years with good reports

arguments.claim: No cheating of Service Commission under latter part of s. 415 as no likelihood of damage to reputation despite deception

anchor.surface_text: Assuming, without deciding, that such a deception of the Service Commission and its recommendation could, in certain circumstances, cause damage to its reputation, we are of opinion that in the circumstances of this case there was no likelihood of the causing of such damage to its reputation. There is nothing on the record to show that the Service Commission could have ordinarily detected the deception or that the appointment of the applicant to the post in the Medical Service was the appointment of a person who proved to be inefficient.

arguments.claim: No cheating by obtaining admission card as no competitive written examination took place, only interview

anchor.surface_text: There is no force in this contention for the simple reason that there is nothing on the record to indicate that an admission card was issued entitling the appellant to sit at the competitive examination. In fact, no examination as such took place, and the contention for the respondent appears to have been made under a misapprehension arising out of the letter of the Secretary of the Service Commission to the Surgeon-General with the Government of Madras stating that he was enclosing the list containing the names and other particulars of 45 candidates who were successful at the competitive examination held by the Commission for the direct recruitment of Civil Assistant Surgeons, Class II Men in the Madras Medical Service.

arguments.claim: Appointments made by Government on recommendation of Service Commission which selects and sends list with qualifications

anchor.surface_text: We accept the contention for the respondent. The appointments to the Medical Services are made by Government. The Service Commission simply selected the candidates and recommends their names to Government for appointment. This is clear from letter Exhibit P. 47 from the Secretary to the Service Commission to the Surgeon-General with the Government of Madras. The letter refers to the enclosing of a list containing the names and other particulars of the candidates who were successful at the examination,

arguments.claim: Misrepresentation in application to Service Commission continues till considered by Government, the appointing authority

anchor.surface_text: Any representation made in an application for appointments is really a representation made to the Government, the appointing authority, and not only to the Public Service Commission to which the application is presented and which has to deal with that application in the first instance. up to the stage ,of selection. The object of the applicant was to secure an appointment and not merely to deceive the Public Service Commission and sit at the examination or to appear at the interview.

arguments.claim: Government deceived by misrepresentation as Service Commission sent list with qualifications including appellant's MBBS, leading to belief and appointment

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the appellants misrepresentation to the Service Commission continued and persisted till the final stage of the Government passing an order of appointment and that therefore the Government itself was deceived by the misrepresentation he had made in his application presented to the Service Commission.

arguments.claim: Deception of independent statutory adviser like Public Service Commission is deception of Government

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the Service Commission is an independent statutory authority has no relevant bearing on this question. It is a statutory body as it is constituted under he provisions Of -a statutes. It is independent of the Government in the sense that in its selection of candidates or in its tendering advice to the Government it does not take any hint or instructions or due from the Government.

arguments.claim: Precedents hold deception of agent/servant is deception of principal, applying to PSC and Government
Public Service Commission independent statutory body under Government of India Act 1935 ss.241,264,266

anchor.surface_text: This is also clear from the provisions of the Government of India Act, 1935. Section 241 provided that appointments in connection with the affairs of a Province will be made by the Governor of the Province. Sub-s. (1) of s. 266 makes it a duty of the Provincial Public Service Commission to conduct examinations for appointments to the Services of a Province.

arguments.claim: Precedent State of U.P. v. Manbodhan Lal Srivastava emphasizes PSC independence for unbiased advice

anchor.surface_text: This aspect of a Public Service Commission was emphasized in State of U.P. v. Manbodhan Lal Srivastava 1 when considering the corresponding provisions of art. 320 of the Constitution. This Court said Once, relevant regulations have been made, they are meant to be followed in letter and in spirit and it goes without saying that consultation with the Commission on all disciplinary matters affecting a public servant has been specifically provided for in order, first, to give an assurance to the Services that a wholly independent body,

holdings.text: the appellant has not committed the offence of cheating as defined in the latter part of s. 415 I.P.C., even though he had deceived the Service Commission by representing himself to be a duly qualified candidate, and thus induced it to select him for the post

anchor.surface_text: His incompetency for the post was due to his having not obtained the minimum academic qualifications prescribed for the candidates for these posts. We are therefore of opinion that the appellant has not committed the offence of cheating as defined in the latter part of s. 415 I.P.C., even though he had deceived the Service Commission by re-

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence Service Commission would detect deception or appellant inefficient; served efficiently for 10 years with good reports from superiors

holdings.text: cannot hold that the offence of cheating by dishonestly inducing the Service Commission to deliver him property was committed by the appellant

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, we cannot hold merely on the basis of suggestions, that any competitive written examination was held and that any admission card was issued to the appellant entitling him to sit at the examination and, consequently, cannot hold that the offence of cheating by dishonestly inducing the Service Commission to deliver him property was committed by the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No record evidence of competitive written examination or admission card issuance; candidates only interviewed per lower court judgments and exhibits

holdings.text: The appointments to the Medical Services are made by Government. The Service Commission simply selected the candidates and recommends their names to Government for appointment

anchor.surface_text: The ap- pointments to the Medical Services are made by Government. The Service Commission simply selected the candidates and recommends their names to Government for appointment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Confirmed by Service Commission letter Ex. P-47 sending list of successful candidates with particulars and qualifications to Surgeon-General

holdings.text: Any representation made in an application for appointments is really a representation made to the Government, the appointing authority, and not only to the Public Service Commission

anchor.surface_text: Any representation made in an application for appointments is really a representation made to the Government, the appointing authority, and not only to the Public Service Commission to which the application is presented and which has to deal with that application in the first instance. up to the stage ,of selection.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Object of applicant is appointment by Government; PSC sends recommendation with qualifications relied upon by Government

holdings.text: the appellants misrepresentation to the Service Commission continued and persisted till the final stage of the Government passing an order of appointment and that therefore the Government itself was deceived by the misrepresentation he had made in his application presented to the Service Commission

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the appellants misre- presentation to the Service Commission continued and persisted till the final stage of the Government passing an order of appointment and that therefore the Government itself was deceived by the misrepresentation he had made in his application presented to the Service Commission.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Service Commission forwarded list with qualifications including appellant's claimed MBBS degree; Government believed and scrutinized via PSC

holdings.text: Deception of such an adviser [Public Service Commission] is deception of the Government which is expected to pay heed to its advice and act accordingly

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the Service Commission is an independent statutory authority has no relevant bearing on this question. It is a statutory body as it is constituted under he provisions Of -a statutes. It is independent of the Government in the sense that in its selection of candidates or in its tendering advice to the Government it does not take any hint or instructions or due from the Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: PSC functions as statutory adviser to Government on recruitment; independent status does not break chain of deception

holdings.text: The principle of the cases, to our mind, fully applies to the case of candidates deceiving the Public Service Commission and thereby deceiving the Government in believing that they satisfied the various conditions prescribed for candidates for those appointments

anchor.surface_text: There have been cases in which servants or agents of an authority have been deceived while the loss has been suffered by the authority concerned. In such cases, the person deceiving the servants or agents has been held to have deceived the authority concerned, though no direct question was raised about the deception being made not to the authority but to is servant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents establish deception of agent/servant/officer constitutes deception of principal/authority (citing Crown v. Gunput, Billinghurst v. Blackburn, etc.)

precedents.citation: State of U.P. v. Manbodhan Lal Srivastava 1

anchor.surface_text: State of U.P. v. Manbodhan Lal Srivastava 1  when companysidering the companyresponding provisions of art. 320 of the Constitution. This Court said Once, relevant regulations have been made, they are meant to be followed in letter and in spirit and it goes without saying that companysultation with the Commission on all disciplinary matters affecting a public servant has been specifically provided for in order, first, to give an assurance to the Services that a wholly independent body, number directly companycerned with the making of orders adversely affecting public servants, has companysidered the action proposed to be taken against a particular public servant, with an open mind and, secondly, to afford the Government unbiassed advice and opinion on matters vitally affecting the morale of public services.

precedents.case_name: State of U.P. v. Manbodhan Lal Srivastava
precedents.cited_proposition: Public Service Commission is a statutory body independent of the Government providing unbiased advice on matters affecting public services
precedents.cited_holding: Once, relevant regulations have been made, they are meant to be followed in letter and in spirit and it goes without saying that companysultation with the Commission on all disciplinary matters affecting a public servant has been specifically provided for in order, first, to give an assurance to the Services that a wholly independent body, number directly companycerned with the making of orders adversely affecting public servants, has companysidered the action proposed to be taken against a particular public servant, with an open mind and, secondly, to afford the Government unbiassed advice and opinion on matters vitally affecting the morale of public services.

anchor.surface_text: In the Crown v. Gunput 1  the accused who had produced a railway pass with an altered number before the ticket companylector when traveling by a train, was held to have thereby dishonestly induced the railway companypany to do or omit to do what they otherwise would number have done or omitted by the production of the altered pass. The deception of the ticket companylector was companysidered to be deception of the railway companypany.

precedents.cited_proposition: Deception of the ticket collector constitutes deception of the railway company
precedents.cited_holding: the accused who had produced a railway pass with an altered number before the ticket companylector when traveling by a train, was held to have thereby dishonestly induced the railway companypany to do or omit to do what they otherwise would number have done or omitted by the production of the altered pass. The deception of the ticket companylector was companysidered to be deception of the railway companypany.

precedents.citation: P. E. Billinghurst v. H. P. Blackburn 2

anchor.surface_text: In P. E. Billinghurst v. H. P. Blackburn 2  certain bills were presented by a companypany for payment. They were checked by Government officials who were deceived by certain repre- sentations made by subordinate officials through whom the bills had passed, and companysequently payments were made in satisfaction of the demands under the bills. The persons companycerned in causing the deception were companyvicted of cheating the Government.

precedents.case_name: P. E. Billinghurst v. H. P. Blackburn
precedents.cited_proposition: Deception of government officials by subordinate representations leading to payments constitutes cheating the Government
precedents.cited_holding: certain bills were presented by a companypany for payment. They were checked by Government officials who were deceived by certain repre- sentations made by subordinate officials through whom the bills had passed, and companysequently payments were made in satisfaction of the demands under the bills. The persons companycerned in causing the deception were companyvicted of cheating the Government.

precedents.citation: Legal Remembrancer v. Manmatha Bhusan Chatterjee and Legal Remembrancer v. Hridoy Narain 3

anchor.surface_text: In Legal Remembrancer v. Manmatha Bhusan Chatterjee and Legal Remembrancer v. Hridoy Narain 3  it was held that if the evidence showed that responsible officers of the East Indian Railway Company and its Asansol Office were deceived and induced either to allot wagons to a certain companyliery which would number otherwise have been allotted or to make out wagon chalans for the companyliery which would number otherwise have been made, it was sufficient to support the allegations in the charges that the railway companypany was, by reason of deceipt, induced to act in a certain way.

precedents.case_name: Legal Remembrancer v. Manmatha Bhusan Chatterjee and Legal Remembrancer v. Hridoy Narain
precedents.cited_proposition: Deception of responsible officers of railway company constitutes deception of the company inducing it to act in a certain way
precedents.cited_holding: if the evidence showed that responsible officers of the East Indian Railway Company and its Asansol Office were deceived and induced either to allot wagons to a certain companyliery which would number otherwise have been allotted or to make out wagon chalans for the companyliery which would number otherwise have been made, it was sufficient to support the allegations in the charges that the railway companypany was, by reason of deceipt, induced to act in a certain way. The deception of the responsible officers was thus taken to be the deception of the railway companypany

anchor.surface_text: In Emperor v. Fazal Din 4  it was held that the deception practised was likely to cause damage or harm to the person on whom it was practised or to the railway authorities whose agent he was in the matter of appointments.

precedents.cited_proposition: Deception practised on an agent is likely to cause damage or harm to the railway authorities whose agent he was
precedents.cited_holding: the deception practised was likely to cause damage or harm to the person on whom it was practised or to the railway authorities whose agent he was in the matter of appointments.

anchor.surface_text: In Queen-Empress v. Appasaimi 1  the act of the accused in obtaining, by personation, a hall ticket from the Superintendent at a University Examination and in signing the name of another person on the examination papers was held to indicate an intention on his part to lead the University authorities to believe that the examination papers were answered by the other person.

precedents.cited_proposition: Deception of the Superintendent working for the University constitutes deception of the University itself
precedents.cited_holding: the act of the accused in obtaining, by personation, a hall ticket from the Superintendent at a University Examination and in signing the name of another person on the examination papers was held to indicate an intention on his part to lead the University authorities to believe that the examination papers were answered by the other person. This again is on the principle that the deception of the Superintendent who was working for the University was a deception of the University itself.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, in Ashwini Kumar Gupta v. Emperor 2  the accused personated another person at a University examination cheating the Registrar. It was held that this number only damaged the reputation of the Registrar, but also that of the University.

precedents.cited_proposition: Personation at university examination cheating the Registrar damages the reputation of the University
precedents.cited_holding: the accused personated another person at a University examination cheating the Registrar. It was held that this number only damaged the reputation of the Registrar, but also that of the University.

anchor.surface_text: Reference may also be made to the case reported as In re Hampshire Land Company 3  in which a Society had lent money to a companypany on the borrowing of the directors of that companypany who were number companypetent to borrow, the resolution companyferring on them the power of borrowing being invalid for certain reasons. It was held that the Society had a right to assume, in a case like that, that all the essentials of internal management had been carried out by the borrowing companypany.

precedents.cited_proposition: A lender has a right to assume that essentials of internal management have been carried out by the borrowing company
precedents.cited_holding: a Society had lent money to a companypany on the borrowing of the directors of that companypany who were number companypetent to borrow, the resolution companyferring on them the power of borrowing being invalid for certain reasons. It was held that the Society had a right to assume, in a case like that, that all the essentials of internal management had been carried out by the borrowing companypany.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the Service Commission is an independent statutory authority has no relevant bearing on this question.
